dt: {bc}to conform one's action or practice to (something, such as a law, rite, or condition) {bc}comply with

dt.t: failed to {wi}observe{/wi} the law and as a consequence had to pay a fine

dt: {bc}to inspect or take note of as an augury, omen, or presage

dt.t: {it}observed{/it} the flight of the sacred geese

dt: {bc}to celebrate or solemnize (something, such as a ceremony or festival) in a customary or accepted way
{bc}to watch carefully especially with attention to details or behavior for the purpose of arriving at a judgment
{bc}to make a scientific {a_link|observation} on or of

dt.t: {it}observed{/it} the mating habits of the grouse

dt: {bc}to come to realize or know especially through consideration of noted facts

dt.t: … {it}observed{/it} that the indefinite reduction of any given risk to society often brings with it an increase in other risks.
"The paint," she {it}observed{/it}, "is already starting to peel."
When your teacher is demonstrating something, sit up and {wi}observe{/wi}!
Perform your tricks, and we will {wi}observe{/wi}.
In her speech she {it}observed{/it} on the changing climate.

pt: {sc}keep{/sc} {sc}observe{/sc} {sc}celebrate{/sc} {sc}commemorate{/sc} mean to notice or honor a day, occasion, or deed. {sc}keep{/sc} stresses the idea of not neglecting or violating.

pt.t: {it}kept{/it} the Sabbath by refraining from work

pt: {sc}observe{/sc} suggests marking the occasion by ceremonious performance.
{sc}celebrate{/sc} suggests acknowledging an occasion by festivity.

pt.t: traditionally {it}celebrates{/it} Thanksgiving with a huge dinner

pt: {sc}commemorate{/sc} suggests that an occasion is marked by observances that remind one of the origin and significance of the event.

pt.t: {it}commemorate{/it} Memorial Day with the laying of wreaths

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}observer{/it}, from Latin {it}observare{/it} to guard, watch, observe, from {it}ob-{/it} in the way, toward + {it}servare{/it} to keep {ma}{mat|conserve|}{/ma}
shortdef: to conform one's action or practice to (something, such as a law, rite, or condition) : comply with
to inspect or take note of as an augury, omen, or presage
to celebrate or solemnize (something, such as a ceremony or festival) in a customary or accepted way

dt: {bc}a weekly day of rest and solemn worship that is observed on Sunday by most Christians and on Saturday (from Friday evening to Saturday evening) by Jews and some Christians

dt.t: We are careful not to {phrase}break the Sabbath{/phrase}.

shortdef: a weekly day of rest and solemn worship that is observed on Sunday by most Christians and on Saturday (from Friday evening to Saturday evening) by Jews and some Christians
